Really Special Tag Line

ABOUT

I am a PhD candidate in the Anthropology Department at the University of Georgia with a M.P.H. in Epidemiology. My work addresses how humans respond to changing nutritional and economic environments through water and diet intake and the significance of these relationships for short- and long-term health and nutrition. My research among Tsimane’ forager-horticulturalists in the Bolivian Amazon addresses an exciting new avenue in biological anthropology evaluating how hydration strategies relate to variation in hydration, water-related diseases, and immune activation during lifestyle transitions.

Contact

Publications

Peer-reviewed Journal Articles
Rosinger A. In Press. Dehydration among Lactating Mothers in the Amazon: A NeglectedProblem. Accepted: American Journal of Human Biology
Rosinger A, Tanner S. In Press. Water from fruit or the river? Examining hydration strategies and gastrointestinal illness among Tsimane’ adults in the Bolivian Amazon. Public Health Nutrition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1017/S1368980014002158.
Rosinger A, Tanner S, Leonard W, TAPS Study Team. 2013. Precursors to over-nutrition: The effects of household market food expenditures on measures of body composition among Tsimane’ adults in lowland Bolivia. Social Science & Medicine 92: 53-60.
Tanner S, Rosinger A, Leonard WR, Reyes-Garcia V, TAPS Study Team. 2013. Health and adult productivity: The relationship between adult nutrition, helminth infection, and agricultural, hunting, and fishing yields in the Bolivian Amazon. American Journal of Human Biology 25(1): 123-130.
Book Chapters
Tanner S, Rosinger A2014. Salud y nutrición: Perfil y cambio, Ch 9. In Cambio Local – Cambio Global: Radiografia del Processo de Cambio en la Sociedad Tsimane’, Amazonia Boliviana. Reyes-Garcia V & Huanca T, Eds. Barcelona, Icaria editorial.
Manuscripts in preparation
Rosinger A. Heat and hydration status: Predictors of repeated measures of urine specific gravity among Tsimane’ adults in the Amazon. Intended journal: American Journal of Physical Anthropology.
Rosinger A, Tanner S, Leonard WR, TAPS Study Team. Setting nutritional pathways: The effects of household market food expenditures on body composition among rural Bolivian children. Intended journal: American Journal of Human Biology.
Rosinger A, Godoy R. 2015. Height and weight of native populations (invited book chapter). InHandbook of Economics and Human Biology, ed John Komlos. Oxford University Press.
Rosinger A. Predictors and health outcomes of water insecurity after a flood in the BolivianAmazon. Intended journal: American Journal of Public Health.
Leonard W, Reyes-García V, Tanner S, Rosinger A, Huanca T, Vadez V, Zhang B, Godoy R. The Tsimane’ Amazonian Panel Study (TAPS), 2002-2010.
